page.title: 12PRISTON CHURCH
page.content: The church, St Luke and St Andrew, dates from the early twelfth century. A Norman lion statue can be seen on the west face. The clock on the east face and a golden weathercock on top of the tower were added in 1813 by the Lord of the Manor. On either side of the porch entrance are two scratch dials. There is a fine peal of six bells, the oldest of which is circa 1500. Twelve bell ringers (6 from the village) practise weekly. Six services are held each month, about 30 people attend the 3 morning services and 10 the three evening services. There are two large old trees in the churchyard, one a yew the other a horsechestnut. The latter needs six people with arms outstretched to measure its girth.
